i,j=1,1
for categ in fiverr['Category'].unique():
    print(str(i)+' - '+str(categ)+' \n')
    i=i+1
    j=1
    for subcateg in fiverr[fiverr['Category']==categ]['Subcat'].unique():
        print('    '+str(j)+' - '+str(subcateg))
        j=j+1
    print('\n')

source.545413eb:
I am going to make a special Kaggle notebook because I'am be the first use of this notebook and seriously need this study. Since selling small services is a raising business domain, it is wise to think about investing in this market if you have a value to share.
Fiverr is a well known freelancing platform that I like so much and it's very interesting to hace an onverview about what's going there. I have some soft skills and Fiverr may be a good place to sell technical services but we're not sure yet let the data tell us if it worth to as a freelancer in Fiverr.

The dataset:

The dataset that I'm going to use for data analyse is a csv file with 6183 row and 7 column, where each row represents a gig (small service) and each column represents a feature, it does not contain all offers available on Fiverr but only a sumple of it.

The main goal behind this notebook is to have a clear overview about the market of Fiverr and to extract the maximum amount of informations and to help everyone who is planning to work with Fiverr in his market study by providing an explained analysis of the available date. This analysis will be to fonded on descriptive statistics concepts. Mainly I will show how quantitatif vary in the hole sample first ,then how they vary in term of each label of qualitatif or categorical valiables.

The quantitatif variable in this dataset are :

  1. The count (number) of gigs.
  2. The price.
  3. The count (number) of reviews.
  4. The overall rating.

The categorical variable in this dataset are :

  1. The Category
  2. The Subcategory.

Here the main questions that I'am going to treat in my notebook:

  1. The distribution of the number of gigs in term of categorical features for the hole sample.

    • Category.
    • Subcategories of each Category.

  2. The distribution of prices of gigs in term of categorical features for the hole sample.

    • Category.
    • Subcategories of each Category.

  3. The distribution of reviews of gigs in term of categorical features for the hole sample.

    • Category.
    • Subcategories of each Category.

  4. The distribution of ratings of gigs in term of categorical features for the hole sample.

    • Category.
    • Subcategories of each Category.

  5. The binary relationship between each two quantitatif variables for the hole sample.

    • The binary relationship between prices and reviews for the hole sample.
    • The binary relationship between prices and ratings for the hole sample.
    • The binary relationship between ratings and reviews for the hole sample.

  6. The distribution of the measures of center (mean and median) for the price of gigs in term of categorical features.

    • The mean price for each Category.
    • The mean price for each Subcategories of each Category.
    • The median price for each Category.
    • The median price for each Subcategories of each Category.

  7. The distribution of the measures of spread (minimum, maximum, standard deviation and interquartile) for the price of gigs in term of categorical features.

    • The minimum price for each Category.
    • The minimum price for each Subcategories of each Category.
    • The maximum price for each Category.
    • The maximum price for each Subcategories of each Category.
    • The price's standard deviation for each Category.
    • The price's standard deviation for each Subcategories of each Category.
    • The price's interquartile for each Category.
    • The price's interquartile for each Subcategories of each Category.

  8. The distribution of the measures of center (mean and median) for the count of reviews of gigs in term of categorical features.

    • The mean count of reviews for each Category.
    • The mean count of reviews of reviews for each Subcategories of each Category.
    • The median count of reviews for each Category.
    • The median count of reviews for each Subcategories of each Category.

  9. The distribution of the measures of spread (minimum, maximum, standard deviation and interquartile) for the count of reviews of offers in term of categorical features.

    • The minimum count of reviews for each Category.
    • The minimum count of reviews for each Subcategories of each Category.
    • The maximum count of reviews for each Category.
    • The maximum count of reviews for each Subcategories of each Category.
    • The standard deviation of the count of reviews for each Category.
    • The standard deviation of the count of reviews for each Subcategories of each Category.
    • The interquartile of the count of reviews for each Category.
    • The interquartile of the count of reviews for each Subcategories of each Category.

  10. The distribution of the measures of center (mean and median) for the ratings of gigs in term of categorical features.

    • The mean ratings for each Category.
    • The mean ratings for each Subcategories of each Category.
    • The median ratings for each Category.
    • The median ratings for each Subcategories of each Category.

  11. The distribution of the measures of spread (minimum, maximum, standard deviation and interquartile) for the price of offers in term of categorical features.

    • The minimum ratings for each Category.
    • The minimum ratings for each Subcategories of each Category.
    • The maximum ratings for each Category.
    • The maximum ratings for each Subcategories of each Category.
    • The ratings's standard deviation for each Category.
    • The ratings's standard deviation for each Subcategories of each Category.
    • The ratings's interquartile for each Category.
    • The ratings's interquartile for each Subcategories of each Category.

  12. The binary relationship between each two quantitatif variables for each Category and for each Subcategory of each Category.

    • The binary relationship between prices and reviews for each Category.
    • The binary relationship between prices and reviews for each Subcategory of each Category..
    • The binary relationship between prices and ratings for each Category.
    • The binary relationship between prices and ratings for each Subcategory of each Category..
    • The binary relationship between ratings and reviews for each Category.
    • The binary relationship between ratings and reviews for each Subcategory of each Category.
